title: Australia readies for cyber 'Pearl Harbour'
text:
“Hopefully we can close this gap in sufficient time before that day, the equivalent of a cyber Pearl Harbour, comes,” he said this week.

'The state will have to step in'

Financial regulators separately warned on Friday that cyber risk is consistently ranked amongst the top dangers to the financial system.

"Cyber attacks are increasing in frequency, sophistication and impact, with perpetrators continuously refining their efforts to compromise systems, networks and information worldwide," the Council of Financial Regulators said.

The latest warnings come after Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton this month said he would “call out” China’s cyber attacks, foreign interference in universities and theft of intellectual property.

"The cyber world that we're on the cusp of is hardly imagined by many Australians," Mr Dutton said.

China, Russia, North Korea and Iran have been identified by the government as major cyber threats, both for geopolitcal and commercial purposes.

Advertisement

China suspected of attacks

Chinese spies are suspected of targeting the computer systems of Australia's three major political parties, the federal parliament and the Australian National University in recent years.

Foreign cyber attackers not only launch immediate attacks on governments and business, but their malware can secretly infiltrate critical infrastructure networks in preparation for a potential attack in the months or years ahead.

The government’s cyber defence and intelligence agencies have the advantage of being able to recognise nefarious foreign online “signatures” used to digitally penetrate systems.

Critical private sector infrastructure the government is considering gaining powers to defend include financial payments systems, the electricity grid, gas and water supplies, sensitive data holdings, traffic management systems and ports.

Under the current law, the private sector can consult with security agencies such as the ASD to receive technical advice on how to negate or handle cyber attacks.

Mr Pezzullo, who testified to a Senate hearing in Canberra this week, said the risk cannot be remediated by the private sector.

Advertisement

“Notwithstanding all of that work, which is advisory in nature, supporting the private sector and providing threat pictures, you'll get to a point on the risk curve where the state will have to step in,” he told the hearing.

You'll get to a point on the risk curve where the state will have to step in. — Mike Pezzullo, Home Affairs Secretary

The government’s cyber agencies can only intervene to stop or respond to cybersecurity incidents with the permission of network owners.

A consultation paper published by Mr Dutton and Defence Minister Linda Reynolds in September notes, “this takes time and gives malicious actors an advantage. In national emergency situations, it may be appropriate for government agencies to take swifter action.”

Reservations to unilateral action

Australian Strategic Policy Institute senior analyst for cyber security Tom Uren said there was a case for government to place obligations on critical infrastructure and to direct private operators to take certain actions during an attack that became a national emergency.

“But I think government unilaterally stepping against a disruptive attack from overseas assumes government knows more than the industry and I don’t think that necessarily makes sense,” he said.

The government is consulting with industry on what safeguards should be put in place to ensure its tools would be used appropriately, such as not having access to customer data on their electricity usage and sensitive personal financial information.

The government’s Australian Cyber Security Centre estimates that there could be up to 50,000 vulnerable machines in Australia.

The move is part of a broader review to update the government's 2016 cyber security strategy to keep businesses and families safe online.
description: The Morrison government is working on new powers to allow security agencies to defend critical private sector infrastructure from a "cyber Pearl Harbour" attack as concerns rise that Chinese hackers could launch an economic assault.
